well batteries are kind of like people

to do the work like moving the car the

so thanks look so so this particular

is expected to solve a lot of these
electrolyte if the electrolyte boils or

at a much wider range of temperatures so
you could get a whole electric car with

cheaper lighter easier or you could get

the implications of all of this or that

the debt crisis there grinds on
investors are worried that Italy could

and bond markets took a major hit
yesterday in the wake of the bailout for
spain Liz alderman joins us now from
Paris to talk about why everyone is so
worried good morning Liz good morning
Catherine so as I understand it Italy's
debt problems are actually not quite as
bad
as those in in Spain and Greece and some
other places at least in terms of the
deficit that it is expected to run in
the next few years so why are people
getting so concerned about Italy now
well at this point it all comes down to
the issue of growth which is what the
prime minister mario monti has been
trying to push especially since he came
into power in November in this in an
emergency after silvio berlusconi was
pushed out mr. Monti is basically
banging the drum for growth in his
country but the problem is that despite
Italy's you know large size it's
relatively much more wealthy than a
number of the other countries that have
succumbed to the crisis the fear is that
the Italian economy will simply not be
able to grow as quickly as is needed to
reduce what is really still a mountain
of debt that the country has shouldered
for a long time and that is quite likely

footing a larger portion of the bill to

days with a very large 100 billion euro

everybody contributes to that and you
know the concern is that over time if
things were possibly to get somewhat
worse in Spain despite this backstop
that some of the bigger countries Italy
as well as Germany and France would have
to basically continue footing a much

you know don't forget that the this

there's a lot of concern that if voters

all bets are off as to what could happen
with Greece could it possibly eventually
move toward an exit of the euro for all
of these reasons the concern has been
mounting once again since we've seen a
lot of dominoes falling as to whether
Italy
maybe be the next in line and what
happens if Italy is well as many people

to fail people have said that about

the third largest economy in the

really people hope that it won't get to

there there are many national icons
brand Italy companies like Ferrari

nobody cared about that before but since

with this toxic combination of low

in spades well thanks Liz for joining us
Thank You Catherine finally the slow
death of American manufacturing has
taken its toll on small towns across the
United States but in one Ohio town the
pot excuse me the pottery industry has
found an unlikely Savior Starbucks
Stephanie Strom has been following the
story and she joins me now Stephanie
thanks for being here thank you for
having me so you went to a town in Ohio
where they seem to be having a bit of a
renaissance or hopefully having a bit of
a renaissance in terms of getting more
orders for their pottery how did that
come about that came about after a man
named Ulrich onek Heusen who owns a
table we're very successful tableware
business in Northern California heard
Howard Schultz the chairman of starbucks
inveigh against dysfunctionality in
Washington and tell American businesses
that they needed to do something about
it since the politicians weren't going
to do anything about it mr. Hoek Hausen
had been looking around for new
manufacturing facility and had been
thinking well maybe i'll do it in
northern california he then talked to
some friends and they said well why
don't you look at East Liverpool Ohio
this used to be the pottery capital of
America
and when he he got in touch with Clyde
McClellan who owns this small pottery
called American Magan Stein and he
realized that it would be better to
invest that way because there's an
infrastructure around the pottery
business in Ohio there's clay there's
mold makers all these other things
because it used to be exact power hasn't
exactly exactly and so he then went to
starbuck mr. Honohan starbucks and said
you know you guys have this you've been
telling us we need to create jobs i want
to start creating jobs would you create
a market for these products if I made
them here well so that's interesting you
know there's the sort of patriotic
political piece of all of this but
clearly businesses are not going to
start creating jobs or ordering
american-made products if it doesn't
help their bottom line so how is it that
this was in Starbucks's interest or
other companies for that matter to order
products from here as opposed to places
like China where labor is cheaper well
you know mr. Schultz at starbucks will
say this is more expensive than they
could have done it in China but the fact
of the matter is that labor costs are
becoming more expensive in China making
it less attractive that's been its
primary attraction also manufacturers
there are typically geared for massive
orders hundreds of thousands and it
takes three months or more you have
shipping costs you have duty costs so
American companies are starting to look
at their supply chains more holistically
and saying okay well labor is a piece of
the cost but so is transportation so is
customs duties so is time so is the
inventory that I have to carry what if i
order 200,000 mugs from china and only
20,000 of them sell i'm stuck with this
inventory I can order 20,000 mugs from
American Megan Stein they can have it
into my stores within you know a month
or so and if they sell really well I can
quickly reorder them because so how
representative is this type of thinking
terms of American companies that are in
need of manufactured products are there
other companies that are using sort of
the same line of reasoning and deciding
to place their orders in the United
States it's you know the academics who
study this will tell you that's a little
bit up for debate they're a little
skeptical but there are other companies
who have brought manufacturing back on
shore GE in 2009 announced that it would
start building two plants that are now
operational to build very sophisticated
batteries not your type you know a
triple a or double a batteries but
batteries for things like electrics are
so hiring yes yeah well thank you very
much for joining me thank you for having
me that's all for today please stay with
us online at nytimes.com for our
